--- title: Deep dive into ggplot2 layers - I subtitle: Lecture 1 title-slide-attributes: data-background-image: ../vizdata-bg.png data-background-size: stretch data-slide-number: none format: revealjs highlight-style: a11y execute: code-link: true --- # Warm up ## Announcements - Office hours + locations finalized at [vizdata.org/course-team.html](https://vizdata.org/course-team.html). - ??? ## Setup ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="|1-4|6-7|9-10|12-19"} # load packages library(tidyverse) library(openintro) library(countdown) # set theme for ggplot2 ggplot2::theme_set(ggplot2::theme_minimal(base_size = 14)) # set width of code output options(width = 65) # set figure parameters for knitr knitr::opts_chunk$set( fig.width = 7, # 7" width fig.asp = 0.618, # the golden ratio fig.retina = 3, # dpi multiplier for displaying HTML output on retina fig.align = "center", # center align figures dpi = 300 # higher dpi, sharper image ) ``` ::: # A/B testing ## Data: Sale prices of houses in Duke Forest ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} - Data on houses that were sold in the Duke Forest neighborhood of Durham, NC around November 2020 - Scraped from Zillow - Source: `openintro::duke_forest` ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ![](images/duke_forest_home.jpg){fig-alt="Modernist house in Duke Forest" fig-align="right"} ::: ::: ## `openintro::duke_forest` ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} library(tidyverse) library(openintro) glimpse(duke_forest) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Rows: 98 Columns: 13 $ address "1 Learned Pl, Durham, NC 27705", "1616 Pine… $ price 1520000, 1030000, 420000, 680000, 428500, 45… $ bed 3, 5, 2, 4, 4, 3, 5, 4, 4, 3, 4, 4, 3, 5, 4,… $ bath 4.0, 4.0, 3.0, 3.0, 3.0, 3.0, 5.0, 3.0, 5.0,… $ area 6040, 4475, 1745, 2091, 1772, 1950, 3909, 28… $ type "Single Family", "Single Family", "Single Fa… $ year_built 1972, 1969, 1959, 1961, 2020, 2014, 1968, 19… $ heating "Other, Gas", "Forced air, Gas", "Forced air… $ cooling central, central, central, central, central,… $ parking "0 spaces", "Carport, Covered", "Garage - At… $ lot 0.97, 1.38, 0.51, 0.84, 0.16, 0.45, 0.94, 0.… $ hoa NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, … $ url "https://www.zillow.com/homedetails/1-Learne… ``` ::: ::: ## A simple visualization ::: panel-tabset ## Code ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(duke_forest, aes(x = area, y = price)) + geom_point(alpha = 0.7, size = 2) + geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE, size = 0.7) + labs( x = "Area (square feet)", y = "Sale price (USD)", title = "Price and area of houses in Duke Forest" ) ``` ::: ## Plot ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](01-layers-1_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-4-1.png){fig-align='center' width=2100} ::: ::: ::: ## New variable: `decade_built` ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} duke_forest <- duke_forest |> mutate(decade_built = (year_built %/% 10) * 10) duke_forest |> select(year_built, decade_built) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 98 × 2 year_built decade_built 1 1972 1970 2 1969 1960 3 1959 1950 4 1961 1960 5 2020 2020 6 2014 2010 7 1968 1960 8 1973 1970 9 1972 1970 10 1964 1960 # … with 88 more rows ``` ::: ::: ## New variable: `decade_built_cat` ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} duke_forest <- duke_forest |> mutate( decade_built_cat = case_when( decade_built <= 1940 ~ "1940 or before", decade_built >= 1990 ~ "1990 or after", TRUE ~ as.character(decade_built) ) ) duke_forest |> count(decade_built_cat) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 6 × 2 decade_built_cat n 1 1940 or before 8 2 1950 26 3 1960 32 4 1970 11 5 1980 13 6 1990 or after 8 ``` ::: ::: ## A slightly more complex visualization ::: panel-tabset ## Code ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot( duke_forest, aes(x = area, y = price, color = decade_built_cat) ) + geom_point(alpha = 0.7, show.legend = FALSE) + geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE, size = 0.5, show.legend = FALSE) + facet_wrap(~decade_built_cat) + labs( x = "Area (square feet)", y = "Sale price (USD)", color = "Decade built", title = "Price and area of houses in Duke Forest" ) ``` ::: ## Plot ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](01-layers-1_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-8-1.png){fig-align='center' width=2100} ::: ::: ::: ## A/B testing {.center} ::: task In the next two slides, the same plots are created with different "cosmetic" choices. Examine the plots two given (Plot A and Plot B), and indicate your preference by voting for one of them in the Vote tab. ::: ## Test 1 ::: panel-tabset ## Plot A ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](01-layers-1_files/figure-revealjs/bad-taste-1.png){fig-align='center' width=2100} ::: ::: ## Plot B ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](01-layers-1_files/figure-revealjs/better-taste-minimal-viridis-1.png){fig-align='center' width=2100} ::: ::: ## Vote ```{=html} ``` ::: ## Test 2 ::: panel-tabset ## Plot A ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](01-layers-1_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-11-1.png){fig-align='center' width=2100} ::: ::: ## Plot B ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](01-layers-1_files/figure-revealjs/better-taste-gray-rainbow-1.png){fig-align='center' width=2100} ::: ::: ## Vote ```{=html} ``` ::: # What makes figures bad? ## Bad taste ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](01-layers-1_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-13-1.png){fig-align='center' width=2100} ::: ::: ## Data-to-ink ratio {.smaller} Tufte strongly recommends maximizing the **data-to-ink ratio** this in the Visual Display of Quantitative Information (Tufte, 1983). ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} > Graphical excellence is the well-designed presentation of interesting data---a matter of substance, of statistics, and of design ... \[It\] consists of complex ideas communicated with clarity, precision, and efficiency. ... \[It\] is that which gives to the viewer the greatest number of ideas in the shortest time with the least ink in the smallest space ... \[It\] is nearly always multivariate ... And graphical excellence requires telling the truth about the data. (Tufte, 1983, p. 51). ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ![](images/tufte-visual-display-cover.png){fig-alt="Cover of The Visual Display of Quantitative Information" width="400"} ::: ::: ## ::: task Which of the plots has higher data-to-ink ratio? ::: ::: panel-tabset ## Plot A ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](01-layers-1_files/figure-revealjs/mean-area-decade-bar-1.png){fig-align='center' width=2100} ::: ::: ## Plot B ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](01-layers-1_files/figure-revealjs/mean-area-decade-scatter-1.png){fig-align='center' width=2100} ::: ::: ## Vote ```{=html} ``` ::: ## A deeper look {.center} ::: hand at the plotting code ::: ## Summary statistics ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} mean_area_decade <- duke_forest |> group_by(decade_built_cat) |> summarise(mean_area = mean(area)) mean_area_decade ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 6 × 2 decade_built_cat mean_area 1 1940 or before 2072. 2 1950 2545. 3 1960 2873. 4 1970 3413. 5 1980 2889. 6 1990 or after 2822. ``` ::: ::: ## Barplot ::: panel-tabset ## Code ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="|5"} ggplot( mean_area_decade, aes(y = decade_built_cat, x = mean_area) ) + geom_col() + labs( x = "Mean area (square feet)", y = "Decade built", title = "Mean area of houses in Duke Forest, by decade built" ) ``` ::: ## Plot ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](01-layers-1_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-19-1.png){fig-align='center' width=2100} ::: ::: ::: ## Scaterplot ::: panel-tabset ## Code ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="|5"} ggplot( mean_area_decade, aes(y = decade_built_cat, x = mean_area) ) + geom_point(size = 4) + labs( x = "Mean area (square feet)", y = "Decade built", title = "Mean area of houses in Duke Forest, by decade built" ) ``` ::: ## Plot ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](01-layers-1_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-21-1.png){fig-align='center' width=2100} ::: ::: ::: ## Lollipop chart -- a happy medium? ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](01-layers-1_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-22-1.png){fig-align='center' width=2100} ::: ::: ## Application exercise {.smaller} ::: task - Go to the course GitHub organization: - Clone the repo called `ae-01` and work on the exercise. - Note: For today, this is not a personalized repo for you. The repo is public so everyone can clone it, but you won't be able to push to it. Starting Thursday you'll start getting your personalized repos you can push to. - Once you're done, share your code on Slack in #general. - Label your chunk(s) and pay attention to code style and formatting! ::: ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}

Figure 1.12. ::: # Aesthetic mappings in ggplot2 ## A second look: lollipop chart ::: panel-tabset ## Plot ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](01-layers-1_files/figure-revealjs/mean-area-decade-lollipop-layer-1.png){fig-align='center' width=2100} ::: ::: ## Code ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot( mean_area_decade, aes(y = decade_built_cat, x = mean_area) ) + geom_point(size = 4) + geom_segment(aes( x = 0, xend = mean_area, y = decade_built_cat, yend = decade_built_cat )) + labs( x = "Mean area (square feet)", y = "Decade built", title = "Mean area of houses in Duke Forest, by decade built" ) ``` ::: ::: ## Activity: Spot the differences \| {.smaller} ::: panel-tabset ## Plot ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](01-layers-1_files/figure-revealjs/mean-area-decade-lollipop-global-1.png){fig-align='center' width=2100} ::: ::: ## Code ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot( mean_area_decade, aes(y = decade_built_cat, x = mean_area) ) + geom_point(size = 4) + geom_segment(aes( xend = 0, yend = decade_built_cat )) + labs( x = "Mean area (square feet)", y = "Decade built", title = "Mean area of houses in Duke Forest, by decade built" ) ``` ::: ## Discussion Can you spot the differences between the code here and the one provided in the previous slide? Are there any differences in the resulting plot? Work in a pair (or group) to answer. ```{=html} ``` ::: ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}

``` ::: ::: ## Global vs. layer-specific aesthetics - Aesthetic mappings can be supplied in the initial `ggplot()` call, in individual layers, or in some combination of both. - Within each layer, you can add, override, or remove mappings. - If you only have one layer in the plot, the way you specify aesthetics doesn't make any difference. However, the distinction is important when you start adding additional layers. ## Activity: Spot the differences I\| {.smaller} ::: task Do you expect the following plots to be the same or different? If different, how? Discuss in a pair (or group) without running the code and sketch the resulting plots based on what you think the code will produce. ::: ::: panel-tabset ## Plot ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} # Plot A ggplot(duke_forest, aes(x = area, y = price)) + geom_point(aes(color = decade_built_cat)) ``` ```{.r .cell-code} # Plot B ggplot(duke_forest, aes(x = area, y = price)) + geom_point(color = "blue") ``` ```{.r .cell-code} # Plot C ggplot(duke_forest, aes(x = area, y = price)) + geom_point(color = "#a493ba") ``` ::: ## Discussion ```{=html} ``` ::: ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}

``` ::: ::: ## Wrap up ::: task Think back to all the plots you saw in the lecture, without flipping back through the slides. Which plot first comes to mind? Describe it in words. ::: ```{=html} ``` # Geoms ## Geoms - Geometric objects, or **geoms** for short, perform the actual rendering of the layer, controlling the type of plot that you create - You can think of them as "the geometric shape used to represent the data" ## One variable - Discrete: - `geom_bar()`: display distribution of discrete variable. - Continuous - `geom_histogram()`: bin and count continuous variable, display with bars - `geom_density()`: smoothed density estimate - `geom_dotplot()`: stack individual points into a dot plot - `geom_freqpoly()`: bin and count continuous variable, display with lines ## Aside Always use "typewriter text" (monospace font) when writing function names, and follow with `()`, e.g., - `geom_freqpoly()` - `mean()` - `lm()` ## `geom_dotplot()` ::: task What does each point represent? How are their locations determined? What do the x and y axes represent? ::: ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(duke_forest, aes(x = price)) + geom_dotplot(binwidth = 50000) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](01-layers-1_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-31-1.png){fig-align='center' width=2100} ::: ::: ## Comparing across groups ::: task Which of the following allows for easier comparison across groups? ::: ::: panel-tabset ## Histogram ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(duke_forest, aes(x = price, fill = decade_built_cat)) + geom_histogram(binwidth = 100000) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](01-layers-1_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-32-1.png){fig-align='center' width=2100} ::: ::: ## Frequency polygon ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(duke_forest, aes(x = price, color = decade_built_cat)) + geom_freqpoly(binwidth = 100000, size = 1) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](01-layers-1_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-33-1.png){fig-align='center' width=2100} ::: ::: ::: ## Two variables - both continuous - `geom_point()`: scatterplot - `geom_quantile()`: smoothed quantile regression - `geom_rug()`: marginal rug plots - `geom_smooth()`: smoothed line of best fit - `geom_text()`: text labels ## `geom_rug()` ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(duke_forest, aes(x = area, y = price)) + geom_point() + geom_rug() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](01-layers-1_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-34-1.png){fig-align='center' width=2100} ::: ::: ## `geom_rug()` on the outside ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(duke_forest, aes(x = area, y = price)) + geom_point() + geom_rug(outside = TRUE) + coord_cartesian(clip = "off") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](01-layers-1_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-35-1.png){fig-align='center' width=2100} ::: ::: ## `geom_rug()` on the outside, but better ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(duke_forest, aes(x = area, y = price)) + geom_point() + geom_rug(outside = TRUE, sides = "tr") + coord_cartesian(clip = "off") + theme(plot.margin = margin(1, 1, 1, 1, "cm")) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](01-layers-1_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-36-1.png){fig-align='center' width=2100} ::: ::: ## `geom_text()` ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(duke_forest, aes(x = area, y = price)) + geom_text(aes(label = bed)) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](01-layers-1_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-37-1.png){fig-align='center' width=2100} ::: ::: ## `geom_text()` and more ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(duke_forest, aes(x = area, y = price)) + geom_text(aes(label = bed, size = bed, color = bed)) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](01-layers-1_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-38-1.png){fig-align='center' width=2100} ::: ::: ## `geom_text()` and even more ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(duke_forest, aes(x = area, y = price)) + geom_text( aes(label = bed, size = bed, color = bed), show.legend = FALSE ) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](01-layers-1_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-39-1.png){fig-align='center' width=2100} ::: ::: ## Two variables - show distribution - `geom_bin2d()`: bin into rectangles and count - `geom_density2d()`: smoothed 2d density estimate - `geom_hex()`: bin into hexagons and count ## `geom_hex()` ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(duke_forest, aes(x = area, y = price)) + geom_hex() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](01-layers-1_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-40-1.png){fig-align='center' width=2100} ::: ::: ## **`geom_hex()` and warnings** - Requires installing the [**hexbin**](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/hexbin/index.html) package separately! ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} install.packages("hexbin") ``` ::: - Otherwise you might see ```{=html} ``` Warning: Computation failed in `stat_binhex()` ## Two variables - At least one discrete - `geom_count()`: count number of point at distinct locations - `geom_jitter()`: randomly jitter overlapping points - One continuous, one discrete - `geom_col()`: a bar chart of pre-computed summaries - `geom_boxplot()`: boxplots - `geom_violin()`: show density of values in each group ## `geom_jitter()` ::: task How are the following three plots different? ::: ::: panel-tabset ## Plot A ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(duke_forest, aes(x = bed, y = price)) + geom_point() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](01-layers-1_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-42-1.png){fig-align='center' width=2100} ::: ::: ## Plot B ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(duke_forest, aes(x = bed, y = price)) + geom_jitter() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](01-layers-1_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-43-1.png){fig-align='center' width=2100} ::: ::: ## Plot C ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(duke_forest, aes(x = bed, y = price)) + geom_jitter() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](01-layers-1_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-44-1.png){fig-align='center' width=2100} ::: ::: ::: ## **`geom_jitter()` and `set.seed()`** ::: panel-tabset ## Plot A ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} set.seed(1234) ggplot(duke_forest, aes(x = bed, y = price)) + geom_jitter() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](01-layers-1_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-45-1.png){fig-align='center' width=2100} ::: ::: ## Plot B ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} set.seed(1234) ggplot(duke_forest, aes(x = bed, y = price)) + geom_jitter() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](01-layers-1_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-46-1.png){fig-align='center' width=2100} ::: ::: :::

<script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
